aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Information for Cessna 172L in Idabel, Oklahoma
The accident occurred in Idabel, Oklahoma.
The accident occurred on February 7, 2013, at 12:00 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Cessna 172L.
The defining event of the accident was loss of control on ground.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was CEN13LA167.
The aircraft registration was N7974G.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were no injuries in the accident.
The pilot involved was a solo student pilot.
The solo student pilot stated the airplane began to veer left when its nosewheel contacted the runway.
The solo student pilot attempted to correct with full right rudder.
The solo student pilot was unable to regain control of the airplane.
The airplane departed the left side of the runway.
The airplane struck a drainage ditch.
The nose landing gear was sheared off as a result of striking the drainage ditch.
An examination of the airplane wreckage did not reveal any preimpact anomalies with the engine.
An examination of the airplane wreckage did not reveal any preimpact anomalies with the airframe.
No anomalies would have precluded normal operation of the aircraft.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause of the accident was the student pilot's failure to maintain directional control during landing.
The failure to maintain directional control resulted in a runway excursion.
The finding related to personnel issues was aircraft control by the pilot.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Idabel, Oklahoma

## Date & Time: 
February 7, 2013, 12:00 Local

## Aircraft:
Cessna 172L

## Defining Event:
Loss of control on ground

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
CEN13LA167

## Registration:
N7974G

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

The solo student pilot stated that, while landing, the airplane began to veer left when its nosewheel contacted the runway. He attempted to correct with full right rudder but was unable to regain control of the airplane. The airplane departed the left side of the runway and struck a drainage ditch, which resulted in the shearing off of the nose landing gear. An examination of the airplane wreckage did not reveal any preimpact anomalies with the engine or airframe that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The student pilot's failure to maintain directional control during landing, which resulted in a runway excursion.

## Findings

| Personnel issues | Aircraft control - Pilot |
| --- | --- |

---
